MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Social Welfare Benefits.

Qst.askee: Minister for Social, Community and Family Affairs
Qst.Quest: his views on the allowance of £5 per week payable under the national fuel scheme from October to April to old age pensioners and other recipients of social welfare payments; and if he will increase the national fuel scheme allowance to £10 per week.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. D. Ahern Mr. D. Ahern
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Social, Community and Family Affairs (Mr. D. Ahern)
Speaker.P: The aim of the national fuel scheme is to assist householders who are on long-term social welfare or health board payments and who are unable to provide for their own heating needs. A payment of £5 per week – £8 per week in smokeless zones – is paid to eligible households for 26 weeks from mid October to mid April.

In order to be eligible for assistance under the national fuel scheme, the person must satisfy a means test. A substantial improvement in the means test was introduced in the 1999 budget. A person may now have savings/investments of up to £22,400 or a combined household income of up to £30 per week over and above their pension and still qualify for fuel allowance.
Any change in the rate of payment would have significant cost implications and could only be considered in a budgetary context.

The fuel and light component of the consumer price index rose by 9.6 per cent between August 1985 and August 1999. Any increase in the rate of payment would have to be considered in the light of the modest increase in domestic fuel prices since the current rate of the fuel allowance was set, taking into account the substantial increases in primary payment rates over the same period. In that regard, substantial increases in all the social welfare primary payments of either £3 or £6 per week were paid from June 1999.
Fuel allowances are not the sole mechanism through which assistance is provided to people with heating needs.

There is a facility available through the supplementary welfare allowance scheme to assist people in certain circumstances who have special heating needs. An application for a heating supplement may be made by contacting the community welfare officer at the local health centre.

Where a person would not normally qualify for a heating supplement there is provision under the SWA scheme to pay an exceptional needs payment – ENP. ENPs are payable at the discretion of the health board, taking into account the requirements of the legislation and all the relevant circumstances of the case.

Qst.askee: Minister for Social, Community and Family Affairs
Qst.Quest: the reason potential sales of animals are taken into consideration when processing claims for the farm assist scheme; and the steps, if any, he will take to remove this clause from the scheme.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. D. Ahern Mr. D. Ahern
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Social, Community and Family Affairs (Mr. D. Ahern)
Speaker.P: Farm assist is a means-tested scheme which was introduced to provide weekly income support to low income farmers. Payment is based on a factual assessment of means which is designed to reflect the person's actual net income, i.e., gross income less any expenses necessarily incurred. Income and expenditure figures for the preceding year are generally used as an indicator of the expected position in the following year, although account is taken of any exceptional circumstances in an effort to ensure that the assessment accurately reflects the current situation. Income from the sale of animals would have to be taken into account where it is a feature.

For farm assist purposes, deductions are allowed from net income in respect of qualified children and the balance is assessed at 80 per cent. In this regard, the provisions are more favourable than the scheme's predecessor, the unemployment assistance scheme for small-holders.

Each applicant for farm assist is given a copy of the report upon which entitlement is determined and may request a review if he or she is not satisfied with the basis of the assessment. In addition, any farmer who is not happy with a decision may appeal it to the independent social welfare appeals office.

Qst.askee: Minister for Social, Community and Family Affairs
Qst.Quest: the measures, if any, he will take to streamline the application procedure for the back-to-school clothing and footwear allowance in view of the fact that the procedure is over-bureaucratic and unfriendly to the customer; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. D. Ahern Mr. D. Ahern
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Social, Community and Family Affairs (Mr. D. Ahern)
Speaker.P: The back to school clothing and footwear allowance scheme is administered on behalf of my Department by the health boards. The scheme is designed to assist certain recipients of social welfare and health board payments with the cost of children's school uniforms and footwear. Certain people on low incomes who are in receipt of family income supplement may also qualify.

In order to qualify for the allowance, the claim must be in respect of a qualified child, the applicant must be in receipt of a qualifying payment and they must satisfy a specified means test. A qualified child is one who falls into one of the age groups specified for the scheme and in respect of whom a child dependant allowance is payable.

MainHeading.P: The Comptroller and Auditor General examined the administration of the scheme in 1998 and concluded that the current system of administering the scheme through the health boards should be changed. A working group has now been established to undertake a fundamental review of the scheme as part of my Department's series of programme expenditure evaluations. Over 50 statutory and voluntary organisations and interest groups have been invited to comment on all aspects of the scheme.

The working group will examine all aspects of the scheme, including the procedures for applying for the allowance. The conclusions reached by the Comptroller and Auditor General and the views expressed in the widespread consultation process which is now under way will be carefully considered when the working group is making its recommendations.

Qst.askee: Minister for Social, Community and Family Affairs
Qst.Quest: the proposals, if any, he has to increase the old age pension in the next budget; if any increases will be paid as close as possible to the date of the announcement; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. D. Ahern Mr. D. Ahern
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Social, Community and Family Affairs (Mr. D. Ahern)
Speaker.P: As stated in An Action Programme for the Millennium, the Government is firmly committed to the achievement of an old age pension rate of £100 per week by 2002. An important step towards achieving this objective was taken in last year's budget, which delivered increases of £6 in the maximum personal rates of all pensions. This means that in the two budgets since taking office the Government has moved half way towards achieving the £100 target old age pension rate.

In formulating proposals for budget 2000, I will be endeavouring to make further progress towards achieving the £100 target rate. The question of the level of increases to be provided and the effective dates of those increases are matters for consideration by the Government, having regard to available resources and other priorities.

Qst.askee: Minister for Social, Community and Family Affairs
Qst.Quest: if departmental staff can earn a bonus in their wages when their actions at work directly result in savings for his Department.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. D. Ahern Mr. D. Ahern
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Social, Community and Family Affairs (Mr. D. Ahern)
Speaker.P: There is no direct bonus system for staff of my Department specifically in relation to the achievement of savings from control work.

However, there is a scheme for recognition of exceptional performance by staff which operates across the Civil Service. This scheme has been in operation since 1996 and allows Secretaries General of Departments to make awards for sustained exceptional performance. The criteria for that scheme require that the staff member or group of staff who are nominated operated on a sustained basis above the level which would reasonably be expected in the normal course from the grade of staff involved.

A number of such awards were made to staff in the Department of Social, Community and Family Affairs for exceptional performance during 1998 in respect of a wide variety of activities. The areas covered by the awards included customer service, control, information technology and general administration.

Additionally, there is also the Civil Service staff suggestion scheme called INPUT. The purpose of this scheme is to facilitate and encourage the submission of suggestions by eligible staff aimed at improving Civil Service operations. Qst.askee: Minister for Arts, Heritage, Gaeltacht and the Islands
Qst.Quest: the status of wild mink currently increasing in population in many areas; whether mink are categorised as vermin; the estimated mink population at present; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Miss de Valera Miss de Valera
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Arts, Heritage, Gaeltacht and the Islands (Miss de Valera)
Speaker.P: Mink became established in the wild in Ireland, having escaped from mink farms in the late 1950s and early 1960s. Descendants of these mink, known as feral mink, are now present in every county in Ireland. There are no detailed population estimates for mink but mink densities vary considerably in Ireland and are largely determined by the quality of habitat. While mink numbers can vary slightly from year to year in response to favourable conditions or during the early colonisation of habitat areas, their numbers soon stabilise. Vermin is not a term defined under the Wildlife Act, 1976, but mink are considered an unwelcome predator by many interests, such as the hunter, farmer and fishcatcher who do not wish their game or domestic stocks to be subjected to an unwelcome and agile hunter. As mink are not protected under the Wildlife Act, 1976, they can be freely hunted or controlled by landowners and/or their agents.

Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Arts, Heritage, Gaeltacht and the Islands (Miss de Valera)

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Architectural Heritage.

Qst.hpid: Mr. U. Burke Mr. U. Burke
Qst.askee: Minister for Arts, Heritage, Gaeltacht and the Islands
Qst.Quest: if the appropriate finance will be provided through the national development plan to allow the Office of Public Works to complete fully the restoration works at Portumna Castle, County Galway, in view of the fact this is a major tourist amenity; the full costs involved in completing this work; and if she will make a statement on her Department's intention with regard to this project.

Qst.askee: Minister for Arts, Heritage, Gaeltacht and the Islands
Qst.Quest: when it is proposed to install the oak stairway to the upper floors and to lay down the flooring boards at Portumna Castle, County Galway; when it is further proposed to make ready the library on the second floor in line with proposals for a wild geese library as proposed by the Wild Geese Heritage Research Group; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Qst.askee: Minister for Arts, Heritage, Gaeltacht and the Islands
Qst.Quest: the proposed budget allocation and the detailed work programme envisaged for the year 2000 for Portumna Castle, County Galway; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Qst.askee: Minister for Arts, Heritage, Gaeltacht and the Islands
Qst.Quest: the budget allocated, the expenditure arrived at and the detailed work programme which has been undertaken at Portumna Castle, County Galway, in each of the years from 1997 to date; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Miss de Valera Miss de Valera
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Arts, Heritage, Gaeltacht and the Islands (Miss de Valera)
Speaker.P: I propose to take Questions Nos. 216 to 219, inclusive, together.

A major programme of works, involving conservation and presentation of the castle and its demesne, has been under way at Portumna Castle since 1989. The current phase of works has been funded under the European Union's Operational Programme for Tourism 1994-99, and I am obliged under that programme to complete a project with a strong tourism dimension before the end of 2000.

MainHeading.P: I am pleased to inform the Deputies that significant progress has been made at Portumna Castle under the current phase of works and that the original allocation of £1.6 million for this phase of the project will in fact be exceeded by end 2000. An important feature of my Department's activities at Portumna was the decision to allow incremental tourist access to the castle as works proceeded, rather than close off the site until the project's conclusion. As a result, Portumna Castle and its estate has already contributed to the economic and social development of the Portumna area.
Expenditure on the project during the period 1997-99 was: 1997 – £411,000, 1998 – £399,000 and 1999 (to end of August) £218,000.

Specifically the works since 1997 have involved the construction of some new floors of the castle; expert repair and specialist glazing of the extensive window complex at the castle; plaster conservation works in the stairwell; resurfacing and public lighting of the road from the entrance gate to the marina; research on and preparation of an enhanced exhibition on the lifestyle of the Clanricarde family, as well as major archaeological investigation of the drainage system and subsequent remedial repairs to the drains in order to alleviate flooding in the basement; associated re-instatement of excavated areas; major works to the external boundary walls and paths and surfaces for the herb garden and its walls.

On the subject of the installation of a stairway to the castle, the priority is to facilitate the maximum visitor access to the castle by the end of this phase and, to this end, a stairway of oak and steel construction will be installed next year in the courtyard wing of the castle. This will permit access to the upper areas and meet the essential health and safety requirements of visitors to this national monument.

The current EU funded project will be completed next year with the completion of the first and second floors at the castle; provision of the oak and steel stairway; some additional plaster conservation works; the repair of the chimney stacks and miscellaneous minor works; the provision of an enhanced exhibition and the tidying up of the adjoining courtyard. This courtyard area can then be considered for possible new use. My Department's workforce, which is currently accommodated in this courtyard will, in the meantime, move to the 19th century courtyard located several hundred metres away on the estate where some refurbishment work has already taken place.

Regarding the next national development plan 2000-2006, I have yet to finalise my Department's capital programme of works for that period. In this regard, however, I must refer the Deputies again to the fact that a significant investment will have been made at Portumna Castle by the completion of the current phase of works and that a significant and discrete tourist amenity will be in place as a result.

The Deputies will be aware that a draft management plan for Portumna estate was completed last year and I have received a number of submissions from local interest groups on the contents of that draft plan. I am keenly aware of the proposal from the wild geese heritage research group for the use of a library space at the castle and I will keep this proposal in mind when drawing up my programme of capital works under the national development plan 2000-2006.

Finally, I should inform the Deputies that Portumna Castle is now in the care of Dúchas, the heritage service of my Department, and that the Office of Public Works no longer has responsibilities in this area.

Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Justice, Equality and Law Reform (Mr. O'Donoghue)
Speaker.P: I am informed by the Registrar of Titles that this dealing refers to an application under section 49, i.e. acquisition of title by virtue of long possession, of the Registration of Title Act, 1964, which was lodged on 4 December 1998. I understand that, due to their complicated nature, applications under section 49, which require detailed examination of claims for registration as owners, can take some time to process.

I am further informed that the Land Registry issued a query on this dealing to the applicant's solicitor on 7 September 1999 and a reply is awaited. The query raised must be satisfactorily discharged before the matter can proceed.
Accordingly, it is not possible to estimate a completion date for the application concerned at this stage.
However, I can assure the Deputy that the Land Registry will do everything possible to expedite the resolution of this application.

Qst.Quest: if he will arrange to have a certificate issued to a student (details supplied); and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin)
Speaker.P: The issue of certification of students by institutions is a matter for the institutions themselves. However, I have asked my Department to make inquiries with the Dublin Institute of Technology in respect of the person in question. When those inquiries have been completed, I will advise the Deputy of the situation.

Qst.hpid: Mr. P. Carey Mr. P. Carey
Qst.Quest: if he will expedite the examination of the memorandum of understanding and legal agreement relating to the schools integration project, currently with the legal section of this Department, in view of the importance of the project to a significant number of schools; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin)
Speaker.P: It is my intention that the schools integration project will be introduced with the minimum of delay and every effort will be made by my Department to expedite the necessary groundwork for the project. The Deputy will appreciate that I will be entering into legally binding agreements with third parties in respect of the project and I have a duty to ensure that these agreements are fully consistent with and supportive of the public interest. To that end any contracts must be cleared by my Department in consultation with the Attorney General's office. This work is ongoing and the Deputy can rest assured that there will be no delay in completing it.

Qst.Quest: if a person (details supplied) in County Wexford will be approved for a higher education grant for his attendance at Carlow Institute of Technology as a mature student in view of his medical and financial circumstances.

Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin)
Speaker.P: My Department has raised the case concerned with County Wexford VEC and is awaiting some additional information sought. I will revert to the Deputy on the matter as soon as possible.

Qst.Quest: an gceadóidh sé deontas le haghaidh halla spóirt do Phobal-Scoil Ghaoth Dobhair i nDún na nGall.

Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin)
Speaker.P: Tá iarratas faighte ó Phobal Scoil Ghaoth Dobhair i nDún na nGall le haghaidh halla chorpoideachais.
Is é polasaí mo Roinnese ná hallaí corpoideachas a chuir ar fáil í scoileanna íar-bhunoideachais nach bhfuil teacht acu ar a leithéid de shaoráid cheanna féin.
Beidh oifigigh de chuid an aonad pleanála agus tógála i dteagmháil le Pobal Scoil Ghaoth Dobhair go luath chun dlús a chur leis an iarratas.

Qst.Quest: if he will expedite the appointment of a resource teacher for St. Colman's national school, Macroom, County Cork.

Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin)
Speaker.P: I am aware that the school in question has applied to my Department for a resource teacher post.

The case made by the school in support of its application is currently being assessed by my Department's inspectorate. As soon as this process is completed, the school will be advised of the outcome and arrangements will be made for the immediate allocation of any necessary resource teacher support. I have requested that this process be completed as speedily as possible.

Qst.Quest: if he will expedite the construction of additional accommodation at St. Colman's national school, Macroom, County Cork, in view of the fact the current alternative accommodation is a risk to students' safety.

Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin)
Speaker.P: Earlier this year my Department approved the commencement of architectural planning for an extension at St. Colman's boys' national school, Macroom. The board of management subsequently engaged a design team to prepare a sketch scheme. A proposal was then submitted to my Department which exceeded the accommodation brief approved and the school was requested to submit revised proposals. These are awaited.

It is a matter for the school management to satisfy itself as to the suitability of alternative accommodation for school purposes and of its compliance with all regulatory requirements, including planning and health and safety matters.

Qst.Quest: if, further to Parliamentary Question No. 291 of 29 June 1999 in relation to incremental credit for teaching service, he will arrange to have the circumstance (details supplied) re-examined.

Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin)
Speaker.P: The case referred to by the Deputy is being re-examined. In that context it is necessary for my Department to clarify certain details with the education authorities in Northern Ireland.
The Deputy will be advised of the position by my Department in the near future.

Qst.Quest: the number of vacant school classrooms at primary level in all the primary schools in County Meath; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin)
Speaker.P: The information requested by the Deputy is not readily available and I could not justify assigning scarce staff resources to its compilation. If the Deputy has a query about a particular school I will be happy to provide as much information as I can.

Qst.Quest: when a centre for deaf studies will be established; the status of the proposal before the Higher Education Authority to establish this centre in Trinity College; if he will allocate the necessary funding; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin)
Speaker.P: The Higher Education Authority is at present examining the proposal from Trinity College, Dublin to establish a centre for deaf studies. I understand that the authority has arranged a series of meetings with relevant interests in this field, commencing next week with the Irish Deaf Society and that, following these consultations, a report will be furnished to my Department.

Qst.Quest: the entry requirement for applicants to the Teastas i dTeagasc na Gaeilge course.

Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin)
Speaker.P: The following are eligible to apply to do the course for the Teastas i dTeagasc na Gaeilge: people who hold a full degree granted by a recognised authority for the awarding of degrees, provided that Irish was a subject in the final examination, or who hold an equivalent qualification in Irish; those who have completed a degree course with Irish as a degree subject, but who have not yet been awarded that qualification; those who have obtained a pass in a qualifying examination in modern Irish for an MA course in Irish provided that that examination is run by a recognised university and is of an equal standard to the BA examination; qualified primary school teachers who hold a B.Ed. degree in which An Ghaeilge or An Ghaeilge Acadúil was a degree subject or qualified primary school teachers who hold an equivalent qualification in Irish.

Qst.Quest: the number and names of primary schools in Donegal without remedial services.

Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin)
Speaker.P: All schools in County Donegal with a pupil-teacher ratio of 10:1 or above have been allocated a remedial teaching service with effect from l2 September 1999. There are seven schools in County Donegal with a pupil-teacher ratio of less than 10:1 and currently without a remedial service. The seven schools in question are as follows: Glentogher; Convent N.S., Carndonagh; Creeslough N.S.; Ballyheerin N.S.; Gartan N.S., Churchill, Letterkenny; Scoil Náisiúnta Baile Mór Portnablagh; Scoil Náisiúnta Duchoraidh, Doochary and Scoil Náisiúnta Eadan Fhionnfhaoich, Na Gleannta.
It is open to any of these schools to make a case to my Department for a remedial teacher service. Any such case will be fully considered.

Qst.Quest: if his Department has received an application from Scoil an Linbh Íosa for a full-time resource teacher; when the request will be granted; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin)
Speaker.P: The school in question currently has the services of a resource teacher on a shared basis. My Department has received an application for a full-time resource teacher post at the school. The case put forward by the school is currently being examined by my Department's inspectorate. As soon as the inspectorate has reported, my Department will be in contact with the school authorities.

Qst.Quest: his views on class sizes at second level; the plans, if any, he has to deal with the problem; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Qst.hpid: Mr. U. Burke Mr. U. Burke
Qst.Quest: the plans, if any, he has to reduce class size at second level schools in view of the fact they are now larger than they were 20 years ago, subject choice is further restricted and new programmes and syllabi have been introduced; when he will reduce class size and provide adequate resources to finance these changes; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin)
Speaker.P: I propose to take Questions Nos. 239 and 248 together.
The pupil-teacher ratio in second level schools has reduced significantly in recent years.

The actual pupil-teacher ratio in 1998-9 was of the order of 15.4 to 1. The Deputy will be aware that an additional 225 teaching posts are being created in second level schools for the 1999-2000 school year. In addition, a retention ratio of 18:1 is being applied which has resulted in schools being allowed to retain teachers who might otherwise have been redeployed.

School authorities may apply for an increase in the approved teacher allocation to cater for particular circumstances. Applications of this nature are considered under the curricular appeal process and each case is considered on its merits.
I assure the Deputy that the question of further reducing the pupil-teacher ratio and thereby reducing class sizes will be kept under review in the context of available resources.

Qst.Quest: the position regarding the provision of a sports hall at Scoil Eoin and Scoil Mhuire, Rathstewart, Athy, County Kildare; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin)
Speaker.P: The Deputy will be aware of my recent decision to substantially increase the size of PE halls in post-primary schools. Scoil Eoin and Scoil Mhuire in Athy will benefit from this decision. Accordingly, architectural planning for a PE hall amounting to 806mf7>2 has commenced.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - School Staffing.

Qst.Quest: the number of vacancies for primary school teachers in Kildare in 1999; the number of untrained personnel used to alleviate the problem; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin)
Speaker.P: As the Deputy may be aware the appointment of teachers is a matter for the board of management of each individual school and, therefore, my Department would not have details of the number of vacancies for each school in County Kildare.

A number of primary schools throughout the country employed teachers in a temporary capacity for short periods in September 1999 pending the appointment of permanent teachers. A total of 67 such teachers in County Kildare were paid at the untrained rate by my Department. It should be noted, however, that in some cases the untrained rate was paid pending an assessment of the teacher's qualifications.

Qst.Quest: when a second teacher will be appointed to Kilkea national school, Castledermot, County Kildare; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin)
Speaker.P: The authorised staffing of Kilkea national school for the 1999-2000 school year is a principal and one mainstream class teacher based on an enrolment of 18 pupils on 30 September 1998. This is an increase of one mainstream class teacher on the staffing for the 1998-99 school year.
The school was informed they were entitled to an additional post by way of Department Circular 5/99 which issued to all schools in April 1999.

Qst.Quest: the number of remedial teachers serving a single school; the number of such teachers serving clusters of two, three, four, five, six, seven and eight schools; the plan, if any, he has to reduce the size of these clusters; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin)
Speaker.P: As a result of the recent extension of the remedial teacher service to all primary schools, a total of 1,463 full-time remedial teachers are now in place in the primary system. Details of the number of schools served by the teachers in question are as follows.

MainHeading.P: Each remedial teacher allocation, including those operating on a shared basis, is designed to involve a case load which is in line with the recommendations of the special education review committee. My Department will continue to monitor these allocations to ensure an effective delivery of service.
All second level schools have their own remedial teacher service. A total 560 whole-time equivalent posts are involved.

Qst.Quest: the reason an architect has not surveyed a dry rot problem at St. Attracta's national school, Ballaghaderreen, County Roscommon; when the architect will carry out the survey; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin)
Speaker.P: The board of management of St. Attracta's national school, Ballaghaderreen, County Roscommon, advised my Department of the presence of dry rot on 16 August 1999. An architectural survey will be carried out as soon as possible.
The board of management is aware of the position.

Qst.hpid: Mr. P. Carey Mr. P. Carey
Qst.Quest: if he will renew the provision of support teaching hours to a person (details supplied) in Dublin 16 in view of the fact that the support which he received in the final term of last year was very beneficial to his academic and social development; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin)
Speaker.P: The school authorities recently submitted an application for additional teaching resources to cater for the needs of the person in question. The matter has been referred to the psychological services for a report.
As soon as the report has been received and considered my Department will advise the school authorities and the Deputy of the decision.

Qst.Quest: if he will sanction the appointment of a psychologist to cover the remainder of the primary schools in north County Kildare.

Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin)
Speaker.P: The National Educational Psychological Service Agency was formally established by me on 1 September 1999. The process of recruiting additional psychologists for the agency has begun. Interviews for the new posts are being held at present.

The development of the new service must occur on a phased basis. It is envisaged that all schools will have access to the service provided by the agency at the end of a five year period. It is hoped that there will be the nucleus of an educational psychological service in every county, including County Kildare, by the end of 1999. The service will be organised on a regional basis in close consultation with the clinical psychological services of the health boards which will continue to provide a service to parents and children.

One of the issues which will be considered by the National Educational Psychological Service Agency is how interim support may be provided to students and schools that do not yet have access to its service.

Qst.Quest: the position in relation to the application for permanent recognition for Gaelscoil Uí Fhiaich, Maynooth, County Kildare.

Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin)
Speaker.P: An application for permanent recognition for Gaelscoil Uí Fhiaich, Maynooth, County Kildare, is under consideration by my Department. The school authorities will be notified when a formal decision has been taken in the matter.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - School Staffing.

Qst.hpid: Mr. U. Burke Mr. U. Burke
Qst.Quest: the number of new teacher appointments made in County Galway at primary level for the current school year; the number of remedial posts and resource teachers appointed; the number of national schools without the services of teachers at these posts; the costs of these additional appointments, if any, to his Department; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin)
Speaker.P: An additional 19 teacher posts have been sanctioned for schools in County Galway as a result of improvements in the staffing schedule for the 1999-2000 school year.

MainHeading.P: An additional 16 remedial teacher posts have been allocated to the county as a result of the extension of the remedial teacher service to all schools in the country with a pupil-teacher ratio of 10:1 or more. There are three schools in County Galway with a pupil-teacher ratio below 10:1. The remedial service has not been extended to these schools. However, the schools in question are free to make an application to my Department for such a service provided they can demonstrate a need for such support.

Under a major new initiative in the special education area, all children in the primary system assessed as having special needs arising from a disability are now entitled to an automatic response to those needs. The nature and level of the response in each case will depend on the assessed needs of the child or group of children involved. The response may take the form of full-time or part-time teaching support or child care support, or both, depending on the number of children involved and the nature of their needs.

Prior to the commencement of the current school year, a total of 26 resource teacher posts had been allocated to schools in County Galway. Applications in respect of an additional 14 resource teacher posts for the county are currently being examined by my Department's inspectorate.
The estimated cost of the 35 additional teacher posts allocated to County Galway for the current school year is £875,000.

Qst.Quest: if he will extend the expiry time of control bus passes from 5 p.m. to 10 p.m. for school children who, due to study or sporting involvement, may not be able to avail of the pass before the present expiry time.

Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin)
Speaker.P: Under the terms of the school transport scheme, transport can be provided on either a special service or on public scheduled services.

The term tickets issued under the school transport scheme are designed to facilitate a pupil's attendance during normal school hours, and the validity of these tickets could not be extended to cover extra curricular activities.

Pupils using the scheduled services are in a similar position to those using special services. Such buses do not delay their evening departure time for pupils who stay in school beyond the normal time. Furthermore, the 17.00 hour rule reduces the demand during peak times on the scheduled services.
Consequently, it is not open to my Department to allow students use their term tickets on public scheduled services after 5 p.m.

Qst.Quest: when persons (details supplied) in County Monaghan will know if their son, who needs to attend a special speech class, will be accepted at a school in County Monaghan; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin)
Speaker.P: I am aware of the case to which the Deputy refers.
I have asked my Department's inspectorate to contact the child's parents with a view to deciding how his special needs can best be addressed.

Special classes are established for children with specific speech and language disorders where a need has been identified and supported by up-to-date psychological and speech therapy reports. Speech therapy services provided by the relevant health board form part of the special support package made available to pupils attending such classes.

Qst.Quest: the reason the industry advisers group, as part of the NCTE management and advisory structure, has not been set up.

Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin)
Speaker.P: As part of the necessary groundwork for the establishment of the industry advisory group, I have already set up the national policy advisory and development committee for Schools IT 2000 which includes representatives from the social partners. Included among these are representatives from the Irish Business and Employers Confederation IBEC, an organisation which has members from industry.

In addition, my Department and the National Centre for Technology in Education have also been developing contacts and relationships with the private sector generally and with public enterprise to promote and support investment in educational ICT by business and industry. The success of these contacts is evident from the excellent relationships and partnerships which have already developed. These have resulted in numerous educational initiatives involving ICT both at national and local levels supported by industry. I have had the privilege of launching many of these over the past year.
Now that this preparatory work has been completed, I intend to put in place the procedures to formally establish the industry advisory group at an early date.

Qst.hpid: Mr. R. Bruton Mr. R. Bruton
Qst.Quest: if his Department has guidelines in relation to the timetabling of teachers to teach in subjects for which they have no qualification and in respect of which they have no desire to teach; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin)
Speaker.P: My Department's policy is that, as far as possible, teachers should be timetabled to teach subjects in which they are suitably qualified. Teachers can also be timetabled in some curricular programmes in various modular areas which may not require a specific qualification in a given subject area.

Qst.hpid: Mr. R. Bruton Mr. R. Bruton
Qst.Quest: if his attention has been drawn to the fact that some schools are being forced to cut back on their remedial teaching complement following his announcement of the appointment of home-school liaison posts; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin)
Speaker.P: I am not aware of any instance where the remedial provision allocated to a school has reduced due to the expansion of the home-school community liaison scheme.

Qst.Quest: the reason a person (details supplied) in County Mayo, who works as a resource teacher for traveller children, is not entitled to a full teacher's salary in spite of the fact that she does not require Irish to carry out her duties and teachers who do not use Irish to carry out their teaching duties have been exempted from this rule.

Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin)
Speaker.P: My Department allocates resource teacher for traveller posts to primary schools to cater for the educational needs of traveller children. Pupils from the travelling community are taught all areas of the primary school curriculum, including Irish.

Teachers selected for such post are required to be fully qualified primary school teachers, who, having satisfactorily completed their probationary period, have secured the Department's teaching diploma. Traveller pupils are taught in an integrated setting, either within the ordinary classrooms, where the resource teacher for travellers works in partnership with the ordinary classroom teacher, or are withdrawn in groups for intensive tuition by the resource teacher for travellers.

My Department grants restricted recognition to certain teachers who have a recognised primary teacher qualification from another jurisdiction. These are teachers who are qualified to teach aspects of the primary school curriculum to pupils aged four to 12 years but who are not qualified to teach in mainstream national schools because they do not have an appropriate Irish language qualification. Restricted recognition gives eligibility to teach only in certain categories of special schools and in certain categories of special classes in mainstream schools where Irish is not a curriculum requirement. Resource teachers for travellers do not fall into this category.
The teacher referred to by the Deputy has been granted restricted recognition by my Department to teach only in certain categories of special schools and special classes.

However, the board of management of the school where this teacher is now working as a temporary resource teacher for travellers experienced difficulties in recruiting a suitably qualified primary school teacher for the position. As an exceptional measure, the board was allowed to employ this teacher in a temporary capacity. However, as she is not fully qualified for this post, she is paid the rate applicable to her qualification which is the EU qualified rate.

Qst.Quest: the scheme or facility, if any, whereby a school or group of schools could access funding for the purposes of setting up a counselling service to assist students who have social and emotional problems, disrupting school work and in danger of dropping out of the school system; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin)
Speaker.P: The guidance service in post-primary schools is provided to give counselling support to students who may have emotional and social difficulties as well as to provide educational and vocational guidance. All second level schools have allocations of ex-quota posts for the purpose of guidance and counselling. Schools having particularly acute problems may submit evidence to my Department for consideration of an increase in guidance allocations.

The development of the support teacher scheme in a number of primary schools with relatively large numbers of pupils who experience behavioural difficulties may assist in identifying their counselling needs and also in identifying counselling facilities in local areas, including especially those services provided by the health boards. My Department is in the process of recruiting a national co-ordinator to assist in the development at the support teacher scheme in primary schools.

The National Educational Psychological Service Agency, which was formally established on 1 September 1999, has already begun the process of recruiting additional psychologists. It is intended that all schools will have access to the service provided by the new agency by the end of a five year period. This new service will be organised on a regional basis in close consultation with the relevant services of the health boards with a view, in particular, to the provision of support for children and young people having special needs, including emotional and social needs.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Schools Refurbishment.

Qst.Quest: if he will make a grant available to St. Patrick's infants' national school towards resurfacing and marking of outdoor playing facilities in view of the fact that the present facilities are extremely dangerous and unsafe for children.

Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin)
Speaker.P: An application for grant assistance towards providing a play yard at St. Patrick's infants' national school, Gardiner's Hill, Cork, was received in my Department on 16 September 1999.

MainHeading.P: The question of providing grant aid for the pro ject will be considered following a technical assessment of the existing facilities.

Qst.Quest: the reason St. Patrick's infants' national school has not been granted a concessionary post in view of the fact that it is designated as disadvantaged.

Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin)
Speaker.P: I understand that the Deputy's question relates to St. Patrick's boys' national school, Ballyhooley Road, Cork. The school in question is one of a number of national schools which were designated disadvantaged in 1994. As a result of their designation, the schools in question secured an entitlement to staffing allocations which enabled them to operate at a maximum class size of 29:1. The schools also qualified for supplementary capitation funding at a rate of £30 per pupil. The schools in question were not allocated concessionary teacher posts as part of their support package.

Qst.Quest: when a reliable and adequate bus service will be provided to meet the needs of the children attending Sallins national school, County Kildare; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin)
Speaker.P: My Department has requested a report from Bus Éireann concerning this matter. On receipt of this report, the Deputy will be advised of the outcome.

Qst.Quest: if his attention has been drawn to the concerns of parents regarding the inadequacy and safety of roads, footpaths and general access to St. Wolstan's community school, Ballymakealy, Celbridge, County Kildare; if such matters were given sufficient consideration at design stage; if he intends to provide any improvement to meet these concerns in the near future; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin)
Speaker.P: I understand that there are considerable traffic management difficulties at the entrance to the St. Wolstan's community school in Celbridge. Officials of the building unit of my Department are arranging to meet with officials of Kildare County Council and the management authorities of the school to determine how these difficulties can best be resolved.
